title-group.article-title: Toward a Fully Automated Stock Exchange

abstract.p: Can an automated exchange acting as the only intermediary between ultimate buyers and sellers provide better stock markets? How well a market meets transactors' needs is traditionally characterized in terms of "continuity". In the author's view the presence of occasional large price jumps characterizes efficient markets, and continuity or stability is not in itself a desirable characteristic. The author summarizes his criteria for an efficient market as including low cost, continuous trading, fairness and random price movements. Because the specialist is ordinarily risking his own capital the size of position he is willing to take tends to be limited. One obvious solution is to permit others to participate when he trades for his own account. The larger the specialist's spread, the more incentive investors would have for using participating orders rather than market orders, thus keeping the spread small, attracting a large supply of capital and reducing trading costs for block positioners.
